2laLyY48qcoybx5YJUJE4g.text: nothing tasted good except the booze. the menu had potential but everything was bland. even the tortilla chips sucked. they were half soggy (?!?!)

cFeycgUWj0M1aK1CXSSbcg.text: Monsieur and I are big fans of Mexican food so we were thrilled to find that Wahaca was on the list of new Westfield eateries and visited after a whirlwind of Christmas shopping last December. Although a different layout and vibe to its Covent Garden cousin, the Westfield Wahaca retains the relaxed buzz of the concept. Our favourite plates? fish escabeche in delicious marinade, shrimp ceviche with citrussy tang and nopalitos - bring on the cactus! We love the margaritas and while the sun is still shining I'll be heading back to try their seasonal Devon Crab.

BWjDGIBRYDBP5Ll4tqnjQA.text: My partner and I were at Westfield on Saturday, valentines day, and decided on Wahaca. He had eaten there before but I hadn't. I'm not a fan of spicy food but he assured me mexican isn't too spicy and the menu we looked at clearly marked which items were spicy and which weren't. We were there around 2pm, there was a little bit of a queue but it wasn't too bad and went down very quickly, I don't think we queued for more than 4 or 5 minutes. The menu had a lovely big selection and included a section where it recommended you select 2 or 3 different dishes, or more if you were sharing. They were very reasonably priced, most seemed to be around £3 or 4. In the end we ordered 5 between us. Our waiter was a lovely enthusiastic guy called Rob who was very helpful when we were making our decisions. The food arrives as it's ready rather than all together. This was great as it means you don't wait too long and can start eating as soon as items arrive. My only problem was some items came in batches of 3 which makes sharing complicated! I'd rather 4 smaller items or 2 larger, but it all got eaten in the end. The only thing I wasn't keen on was a black bean and cheese thing. It was like a pancake folded in half, for the life of me I can't recall its name. It tasted great until I bit into a hard bean and it was seriously aniseed flavoured. I can't stand aniseed so I had to spit that bit out, but even then, my mouth was full of the flavour. I'm not sure why that one had the flavour but the rest didn't, I wouldn't have ordered it if I'd read that it had that flavour. Everything else was lovely, I had a sparkling lime drink and it was very refreshing. The bill for two of us came to just below £30 which seemed reasonable.

duj8-EpuBjV4r0q1YyNnQA.text: I have been to wahaca once as a friend recommended it, I loved the food and liked the fact that it is traditional mexican food. I also liked that the food doesnt all come out at once and the small mini dishes were amazing, i had three of them and still had a a main course. definatley recommend to everyone.

7tOKjKi_STWbgsc5Lnn27g.text: i just wanted to see what the big deal was about with Wahaca was i've always planned to go there one day and when i found out that Westfields opened one i had to try it. Composed of two floors, it seemed to have a industrial theme to the decor. the manageress was so attentive and came to me and my friend and accompanied us down to our table which i thought was nice of her. she took our orders of drinks,i tried the agua frescas which was flavoured mexi water.i thought it was a different taste to what i've had before.i was also on a budget so i was impressed that there were meals that were affordable but also pricy. i just had chicken tanga tacos which cost under £4.I did love it and wanted to spoil myself more. we did also get nachos with dip.What was nice is that they place the nachos in a cute pail accompanied with sour cream. it was busy when we went there but not over packed.the service was outstanding and we were asked if we wanted desserts or wanted anything else to eat.i would definetely go back here and an overall good experience

E3rL1KcYzlnjceuP0ZokmA.text: Wahaca - Pics @ The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) I was one of the 30 lucky Qypers (mostly food bloggers) who were invited to taste Wahaca's new autumn menu at their Westfield branch. Having experienced some disastrous meals at other Mexican restaurants in London, I had steered clear of this cuisine until now. I had never visited Wahaca before and was looking forward to the evening ahead. I was truly impressed by the food I tasted, and feel now a growing curiosity to learn more about this type of cooking. Most impressive however, was meeting and dining with the founders Tommi (Thomasina Miers, winner of 2005 Masterchef), Mark Selby and his wife, the gorgeous Cecilia, who runs Wahaca's blog. Their enthusiasm, passion and knowledge of Mexican cuisine were contagious, and made our evening memorable. We had a useful introduction by Tommi and Mark of the dishes that we would be tasting, and the three types of tequilas to accompany them. We started the evening with a lovely dish of Smoked Herring Tostada (£3.75) - shredded smoked herring in a Veracruzan sauce (made mainly of olive oil, capers, tomatoes, chillies and various herbs) on tortillas. I enjoyed this and felt that the fish and slightly tart sauce married well. To follow, we had what I think was one of the best dishes of the evening  Black Bean and Chicken Soup (£6.75). Served with shredded chicken, diced avocado, feta cheese, cream, ancho chillies and totopo (a type of corn tortilla), these were topped by a creamy and rich soup of black beans. The contrasting combination of flavours and textures was a revelation despite the odd appearence, with the ancho chillies giving a spicy but sweet, almost chocolatey quality to the dish. The Huitlacoche Quesadillas (£3.75) with corn, mushroom and cheese, were also good. Huitlacoche is a fungus that grows on the ears of corn, it has a very pungent earthy flavour reminiscent of mushroom and corn. I could easily have a few of those with some cold beer. Their Winter Fuerza Salad (£6.90) was next, a combination of roasted butternut squash, spelt, diced orange, ancho chillies, feta, avocado, and other ingredients. This was a hearty salad, combining two of my favourite salad ingredients  butternut squash & feta. I will certainly try this again. To accompany the salad, we also had Pork Pibil (£3.75), a traditional Mexican slow roasted pork dish from Yucatan Peninsula, marinated in a lime based sauce and slow roasted in banana leaves. This was one of the highlights of the evening, the meat was succulent, sweet and tender. Wahaca's Vegetable Pipian (£7.75) was our next course. Pipian is a traditional mole type sauce used to accompany poultry. It is popular in the North East region of Mexico, consisting mostly of ground nuts, garlic, onions, chillies, and chocolate. Wahaca's vegetarian take was intriguing and bursting with flavours of fresh herbs and ground green pumpkin seeds. The addition of rice and mushrooms was a good alternative to the usual chicken. I loved the richness of this sauce soaked up by the fluffy rice and meaty mushrooms. This was a truly warming winter dish I look forward to trying again. This was followed by Baja-California Fish Tacos (£7.75), crispy fried fish goujons with chipotle mayonnaise in a delicious tomato salsa served on large tacos. This was an easy going dish that anyone would struggle to fault but not particularly memorable in comparison to some of the other dishes. The enchilada with mole (£8.75) was creamy and rich, and partnered well with the tender pieces of shredded chicken, rice and other ingredients. This was a meaty alternative to the earlier Vegetable Pipian; a sophisticated sauce with hints of chocolate, chillies, onions, and garlic. Next on the list was the Fish a la Veracruzana (£9.95), a parcel of Pollock fillet slow cooked in a Veracruzan sauce (made mainly of olive oil, capers, tomatoes, chillies and various herbs) and served with coriander rice. The accompanying fresh salsa was a nice addition to the green rice and fish. The last of our main courses was the Vegetable Burrito (£6), made of toasted flour tortillas filled with coriander rice, and served with corn chips and tomato salsa. For dessert we had a platter of hot, crispy Churros y Chocolate (£3.40). I remember having similar ones in Madrid, although there the hot chocolate was much denser. I found Wahaca's particularly good and preferred the less glutinous texture of the rich hot chocolate. This was the perfect ending to a wonderful Mexican meal. We also tasted three of their finest tequilas  a Blanco, a Reposado and an Añejo (aged version). They had distinct characteristics and were smooth and partnered well with the evening's dishes. It was a great event for which I would like to thank the organiser Chris from Qype, and Tommi, Mark & Cecilia for their kindness and hospitality. It was also a great pleasure to meet people whose blogs I had been inspired by: Su-Lin of Tamarind & Thyme and Mel and

UmvlPU5ofpEQcCYLzdGWrQ.text: Wahaca almost feels out of place at Westfield because it is so reasonably priced! We had a great meal for 2, which with beers, a selection of 'street food' dishes and a 'bottomless' bowl of chips and guacamole came out to around £25. The food was excellent, and the staff really friendly and helpful. This could well become my regular restaurant at Westfield.

UtJQeWm6eQ-u4zx3VM48Mw.text: Having lived in Mexico for years, and having travelled a lot in Oaxaca, this is the closest I've found to the real thing. Highly recommended

Sviygk2Zx9XADSIn2KFVow.text: I was here along with fellow Qypers to sample some of their winter menu ... but a few words about the ambience first. It has that great relaxed, canteen-style vibe about it - and at the same time, a sense of subtle style, that the food is the important thing. The waiters are friendly and knowledgable, and the only problem with the menu was the fine print (ie not all the words were clearly visible) Of the winter sampling menu that I erm... sampled ... the thing that will DEFINITELY be bringing me back will be the corn mushroom quesadilla goodness, the black bean soup (then again, I've always loved black bean soup) and the fish tacos were a pleasant surprise. As was the pollock. The pork pibils dripped off the tongue as they should, and the tequilas were very sharp. A bit too sharp, as I found out the next morning... The prices seemed very reasonable - certainly better than Wagamama's - and a cut above the rest of the faux-posh restaurants that seem to infect Westfield. Definitely a must-go.

LVDf1i8pKr9z0EvFvX30-w.text: I've been to Wahaca four times in total now. The good times have been a visit with a friend who has a mexican wife (and knows the cuisine well) and my most recent, being the Qype winter menu sampling extravaganza. The less-good times have been more 'normal' visits. A quick burrito here, a snatched Modelo and taco there. The differentiator is having someone choose my dishes. I'm pretty clueless about 'proper' Mexican street food, and nine times out of ten will plump for the lowest common denominator burrito / chimichanga / enchilada option, since I'm a shameless SoCa Mexican fast food fan. There's no doubt that Wahaca are serving London's best all-round Mexican menu. What's letting them down are the basics. The chicken burrito is a big (if not physically small) disappointment. Not as good as other burrito specialists that are popping up all over town at the moment. Not as good as some of the more original menu items which could get passed over for the safe option. I love what they're doing with Tequila. It's definitely not a six-beers-down, salt-lick, slug, lemon-slice experience. I liked having it with food. Give it a shot. Stating the obvious, this is the best place to eat at Westfield.

Ug9eXYVabD_Bf9NHALCNug.text: Argh! It's so delicious it makes me want to dance about and toss things off shelves. I'm quite fond of Westfield, following my apprehension before it was built (being a resident of She' Bu'). And it just seems to keep giving. Wahaca (the original place in Mexico is Oaxaca, I think) is one of the restaurants on the Southern Terrace which have some nice cosmopolitan outdoor areas (warmed by earth destroying patio heaters - but oh so lovely) and trendy seating across a couple of floors inside. It's happening, it's friendly, it's reasonably priced. But most of all, the food is flipping marvellous. There's another one in Covent Garden (the first, I believe) and the last time I tried to get in there it was too busy. This is the only problem with Wahaca. But persevere through the crowds, wait those 20 mins to get seated, and order the selection if you don't know what to get. It's ruddy lush.

I5_dMmmYTHeWAHUiGwJBPA.text: This is a well-run Mexican resto so can't find fault with the food, the service and the ambience.

sQoQCipietnR_n9J5okvPA.text: There aren't many reasons I can see for visiting Westfield. As anyone who knows my wardrobe will testify, fashion shopping isn't my kind of thing. And as my bank manager will unhappily testify, general shopping isn't really on the cards at the moment as there's been, er, rather too much shopping on the cards in the past. But the arrival of Wahaca? That's got me looking covetously westwards. Light, healthy, delicious and excellent value - it's perfect shopping fare. It's also good to see a chain expand at a sensible pace. The quality of the Covent Garden original has clearly been maintained here, and the staff are similarly passionate. I've long maintained Mexican is my favourite cuisine. Thanks to Wahaca, people are starting to realise that I'm not insane or addicted to beans

p7pCGmlt8nptTb29RyUnnA.text: In many ways, this is the best Mexican I have had in London.Probably in all ways actually.Apart from some ways that make it not good.To clarify, I'm not sure where I'm going with this.The food is probably the best. Actually, it is. The menu is extensive and innovative and enjoyable and neat in its street food style. The aesthetics are very aestheticy and it is very sleek and fancy. The food is very tasty. My taquitos were excellent and the mini tacos were pretty tasty too. The guacamole was alright. Too red oniony and nowhere near as good as my wife's, but passable once removed. They had a nice selection of cocktails and Mexican beer too. I appreciated that.However, the service is so abominable that it doesn't really matter. Absolutely awful.I mean, pleasant like a stupid dog, but about as effective as a crime fighting companion as said stupid dog, to use the popular aphorism.It could be the best in London. Should be, really. But isn't.So don't come here if you like good service, as it doesn't have it.If you don't care, and love red onion, welcome home.

HMGmp22krbbIFJxblJherg.text: Being a huge fan of Mexican and tapas equally, despite knowing about Wahaca it has taken me quite a while to actually go to one. I always thought my first visit would be to the one in Covent Garden, but as I had tickets to see Florence and the Machine at Shepherds Bush Empire last week I thought I would see what the restaurants had to offer at Westfield. We chose Wahaca over the plethora of other restaurants available and we were pleasantly surprised, although the service was a little slow in places. My cousin and I chose a selection of the 'tapas' style dishes, which was great, because we really couldn't decide on one big main dish each. Unfortunately we were chatting a little too much when we first arrived and had to ask the waiter to come back twice. However, it then took him about 20 mins to come back and find us a third time and in retrospect I wish we had just ordered drinks and some tortilla chips and a dip to munch on whilst we mulled the menu over. The menu is vast and wide, which is great and our waiter gave a very helpful overview of everything that they have to offer, as we were Wahaca rookies. Once we had ordered our food everything came in a pretty timely manner and we had eaten and paid up within half an hour or so. Just a shame it took so long to actually get our order in, despite taking a little while to decide. Would definitely return as the food was tasty and good value.

rX6Z2oJSvcl1wqHpCky0Ng.text: Thomasina has thought of a great idea and been waiting for years for a great Mexican place that is affordable with fresh ingredients and GOOD food. I have had the luck to trave around Mexico and their food is simple, tasty, full of flavour and quick. Wahaca has got this place right. I loved the Frijoles (black beans) and can eat them by the bucket load. Their spicy red and green salsa have a kick about them and full flavour. Westfield albeit clinical is a better place with this place around. You have plenty of choice of food and good to see use of Pork Tacos. You can only seem to get them in the States or Mexico!!! You have the usual Quesadillas, Taco, Tortillas etc and their Burrito is big and tasty. You only need one and for under £7 a bargain. I had to try everything and waiter seemed to know his stuff and choices were all spot on. Is a fav of mine and the price is good with dinner and ate like King and Queen for £30 and £40 inclusive of drinks. We did not drink too much. I have been twice as we are local and do not have to travel to go to Covent Garden. Long live Wahaca in Westfield.

-0XsVVcS-wwk7a7TEWRtGg.text: The service was top-notch. Sometimes when sitting outside, a table gets neglected by the server or busboy not here. Our water glasses were always topped off and the plates were cleared in a timely manner. We never felt neglected a bit.I was a bit apprehensive about coming here due to the mixed reviews, but I have no regrets at all. I'll be back!

vpJcPcRppCUsTfOwj47XwQ.text: I have been to both Wahaca's in London now, the one in Covent Garden when it had just opened and yesterday went to the one in Westfield. I'm sure the food probably wasn't much different but I felt the service in Westfield was really good, considering the size of the place and the amount of people in there. We were given a very warm welcome by an upbeat, friendly member of staff. Fortunately not the Catherine Tate from the Garfunkel / TGI Friday restaurant spoof over chirpy friendliness. As a previous reviewer has said the food may not be authentically real Mexican street food (I've been to Mexico and had street food there) but they certainly haven't taken the easy route of going down the completely bland Tex/Mex route. The pork pibil tacos were good. The salsa that come with the chips very fresh and tangy. The chili sauce on the tables is pretty hot so use sparingly unless you like super hot sauce. It's very good value for money and the price means that you can get to try a number of small dishes, rather than going for a big platter of food. Nice touch at the end of being given a little book of Grow your own chilli seeds.

Tif4k1q5ultsdYxwamWumA.text: Wahaca is a bit like boringly minimalist, much like the other restaurants in Westfield  a bit strange when you're used to Mexicans being more authentic and homely. The food is pretty good however. Although I'm not acutally an expert on the cuisine, there is lots of Mexican street food to choose from, including the usual nachos, burritos etc. All with plenty of cheese and sour cream and refried beans on the side. The prices are fair, especially for an evening meal. Though I would prefer it if they had some kind of special lunch time menu. £10-15 feels like a bit much for lunch, but is fine for tea.

h4rK3rhAZXUla0jPscvI0Q.text: Wahaca wahaca linda! I guess this restaurant is still my favourite but lately it has manage to disappoint me and is loosing it's position quickly against other mexican restaurants in town. It's obviously not my first time in here or any other branch of wahaca and i feel like it's losing the initial passion that you could feel when the company was getting bigger and hotter, this time there's a few things i didn't enjoy as much nor my friend, the pork pibil tacos were really dry in comparison with all the other times, I finally found the problem with the ceviche tostadas they put mayonnaise on them and this ruins the taste completely; I asked a blonde and short distracted manager why is this dish prepared like that (the description in the menu is not accurate) and she said because that's the recipe well i happen to be mexican and that's not the recipe, and it can even be very unpleasant for lactose intolerant. The pork scratches were 50% rock and 50% pork, the chicken tinga tacos were a bit odd and with only 2 tiny cubes of chicken each, and the waiter was very slow bringing the food and clearing the plates. Now on the other hand, the dulce de leche ice cream had a very nice taste with a hit of chocolate chips, the tamarind margarita was well balanced and the michelada well executed, the table was clean, the reception at the door agile and the waiter was polite and receptive but not the quickest, the rest of the team seems to be caring only for their own section and not playing as a team. Ambiance was good and the toilets were well kept. Stations were a bit messy but overall it was ok. I'm changing my rating for a 3 star and hopefully next time i can give this cool restaurant a better rating! see my last review above: (I'm a fan of mexican food and an avid critic of it. Wahaca is a trendy chain of mexican street food, the menu gladly is not texmex or mexican wannabe, they actually have a nice selection of some classic mexican dishes including my personal favourite and a must try; tacos of pork pibil. Quesadillas are really good the cheese is well melted and they use fresh market ingredients. Service is really quick, not as personal as I expect to be served but ok. Hibiscus water is not good at all, but on the other hand the Michelada is well seasoned and they do it with proper mexican beers. Overall is always a good experience to be in any of the Wahaca branches for a quick lunch or dinner first review on 21/03/11)

eptpM0n375we2U5NnwNKDA.text: I don't know what Elaine Y. is talking about....the food IS cheap! I doubt you can eat as cheaply at a restaurant anywhere else in Covent Garden. Dinner for two and alcoholic drinks is around 30 GBP. Also, the food isn't that great, but the restaurant tries really hard. They have a variety of margaritas that sound interesting, but they taste a bit "off" for some reason. They have a nice variety of mexican beers and even have a truly mexican drink (a spicy beer cocktail called a michelada) supporting their earnesty. I can't really pinpoint what the food is missing...maybe there are just no mexicans in the kitchen.

O9iVJhJN9zLTxsJVO4vH1w.text: To start this review I must point out I am from Mexico and love my food, I will also say that this is a very good try at making mexican food compared to other stuff out there.Boasting about being market food and reworking the name of one of Mexico's best states for food (Oaxaca) is a very good idea, the best food in Mexico is found in mercados. However thats as close as it gets to the real thing, most eateries in Mexico will have at least two fresh salsas on the table along with something to dip in it as soon as you arrive. The option is available here, but you have to pay for it. The other essentials are some slices of lime.The staff are very friendly and sport some nice themed t-shirts.Now to the food, the tacos are in the correct tortillas, however they seemed like the long life version sold in mexican supermarkets and not the traditional fresh ones you expect in a market. The cochinita (pork pibil) tasted very much like it came out a tin. The chicken tinga was basically strips of chicken in a watery tomato sauce, when tinga should be desmenusada or shreded meat.The beans looked ok, however they had a strong hint of aniseed, something I have never tasted in mexican beans. The salsas were flavourless, I was specially disappointed by the green salsa that seemed to be missing any tomatillos (green tomatoes). The habanero sauce was also a let down, it tasted sweet.On to the agua fresca that could have done with a little more variety, the hibiscus is called Jamaica over there and is not the only flavour of agua fresca you find (expect horchata, tamarindo, cebada or many other options in a real Mexican eatery).I could go on and on with what was wrong with the food, like no Oaxaca cheese in the quesadillas or the chorizo and potato with no chorizo, however that would be against the point of my review. We are in London and the effort done in this establishment is remarkable, they could have easily taken the easy route and dished out texmex crap that is sold in this country like Mexican food. Wahaca instead tries to give you an idea of what Mexican food is and hopefully will make you save up some money and visit Mexico on you next holiday. If you are going that far and feel adventurous, try and leave your hotel or resort and head for the market.
