U0Fh7jFHHlkFRO9DSUDW_g.text: I've been here twice now and I really love this place.  The food is about as Mexican as you'll get outside of Mexico.  The spicy items are spicy and the flavours are rich.  It's also more affordable than you'd think.Modern ambiance, lively and busy but not crowded.  And while the margaritas are excellent, the limited but tasty selection of tequila for sipping is divine.  If you're looking for something non-alcoholic, the Citrus Fizz is like a mohito without the booze.

mVNy0fvboAEg0CkqTjQncA.text: Mexican food is to an American what a curry is to an Englishman. It's a staple of our diets, particularly if you're an American from one of the cities or states in the US with a major Mexican population. I knew the obvious, which was that there weren't bound to be a ton of Mexican restaurants in London and that the quality of the food wasn't likely to be what I was used to back home in Chicago. But the food at Wahaca is pretty good overall. Stay away from the quesadillas; have the tacos. Try the salsas and guac. Ask for more than one pot of tortilla chips. As for prices - no, this isn't like the typical Mexican spot in the US where you get your endless salsa and chips for nothing. Everything is a la carte and while nothing is individually too expensive, that may be what drives up the overall bill. Of course, it would be a more pleasant place if the service was less pridefully crappy. Most of these reviews are by Americans, and yes, we may have a higher standard for service. But this place is bad even by an English measurement.

1ZaoDu70ZqNJAIzt4uTRZA.text: Waaay authentic especially for London. Food is great. Try the sangrita - it's made from scratch, which is something hard to find even in Mexico, where a mix is usually used.

0OgSynQScr3diDciSGyeIg.text: I love Mexican food and appreciate good service and the two times I have been there I have had a less than satisfactory experience. Both times the same waiter has spoiled what should have been a perfect meal, despite the food being served inconsistently. The waiter was male and has brown middle parted floppy hair, upon greeting us I was under the impression he was pleased to have our custom and we were polite and appreciative back to him. First occasion my wife ordered the steak salad and asked for it rare, it arrived 5-8 mins after my dish and was thoroughly cooked through, she asked for his opinion on whether that was a rare steak, he begrudgingly took at back and returned with a rare one and then said in a patronising tone, eyebrows raised there, is this one better for you?.No apology just that we had caused him a real inconvenience. 2nd visit we had hoped it was just on off day and we are all human we all have off days  up all night, headache, struggling to make ends meet, argument with our partner, etc. And also perhaps we would be lucky enough to get a different member of the waiting staff, but no the same one came and was welcoming enough and helped us choose something he thought we might find tasty, top marks, the food was indeed excellent, but the gap between receiving my food compared with my wife's left me feeling like they had forgotten my order, so she had virtually finished by the time I got mine, no bother though, people forget. Then we came to pay, my wife's card, despite having ample funds on it was declined and his response was to tilt his head raise his eyebrows and announce very loudly and with a patronising tone decliiiiined so every one in earshot could hear, do you have another card perhaps that one has something you can use to pay for it.er actually there's no problem with that account it has ample funds on it, then said in a lower less gleeful way oh well I have been having trouble with this card reader and he tried it again, the payment was taken, no apology and then upon seeing that the tip he was expecting was not given a very quick, terse and sarcastic thank you. Unfortunately until he leaves the service can only be seen from a below par perspective. Just been back this weekend  although why we bothered I am struggling to find the answer to  apart from the food was again very tasty. However this time round we were served by a more friendly couple of waitresses, all 5 of us ordered, 4 meals came and we waited, started eating ours to save it from getting coldand waited and asked the waitress for the 5th dishand waited and she came back and we asked again and were given the excuse oh that one takes longer than the others so I'll see if its ready. Utter rubbish, we watched others who arrived after us getting served the same dish. She returned with it and it had clearly been waiting on the side for some time as was cold to lukewarm. Next we noticed that a portion of rice was missing excuse me we ordered a rice and it hasn't arrived just as we were finishing our meals, so she nipped off and got it, no sorry, and it was charged on the bill.What are you meant to eat that rice with, well there was nothing to eat it with so I guess I answered my own question. The bill arrived and as 5 of us were dining service had automatically been added, why? Do you get any better service if 3 or 4 of you eat, well I hope you don't get worse. Sadly this place has the intention of good mexican food which benefits from the Westfield passing crowd, I wonder how many of the diners give it an ill advised return journey?

XcbSxZZJG15rL_Wb7KfRpQ.text: What an honour to be asked to try the new Winter Menu before everyone else! Being a complete novice when it comes to real Mexican food this was a new and exciting experience made all the more special by having the provenance (MSC fish and locally sourced veg etc) and inspiration of all the dishes explained to us by the passionate duo of Mark and Tommi before we tucked into the feast. Even before then I'd been eating the best guacamole I've ever been served in a restaurant.There were too many dishes to mention them all but the Baja California Tacos were irresistible as were the Quesadilla with Huitlacoche and Mushrooms that grow on corn (Mexican truffles!). The most unexpected pleasures were a wonderfully zingy salad with butternut squash and the black bean soup which was so full of surprises it almost deserves a review of it's own. The bowl was filled with goodies like avocado and roasted chillies and then the black bean soup poured over by the waiter. Each mouthful was different with a burst of fresh coriander in one or the piquant chilli in another. Wahaca is a place where you can trust the chef (cook- sorry!) and order anything on the menu. It seemed that the less likely you are to order something (like the aforementioned soup and salad) the better it is. More standard fare like the Seasonal Vegetable Burrito (still unusual with cabbage in it!) didn't draw quite the same ecstatic response from our table. Other dishes I can't remember the name of were all of a high standard and the often earthy flavours (pipian and moles) appeal to my palette and went superbly with the beer and tequila.The Tequila tasting was also enlightening and I would say of the 3 we tried the "reposada" or "rested" tequila was my favourite being smoother for having been cask aged without the stronger sweetness of the 'Anejo'- 'Aged' variety. All were surprisingly enhanced by the flavours in the food and vice versa.I've discovered a new cuisine that I will definitely be exploring again soon. If you don't know what to order here, my advice would be- Go crazy! It's all great!

8Nysmh6WYoI0HGtHr4GKPA.text: Have visited a number of times now, after wandering into Westfield or purposefully visiting. A friend of mine from Cardiff regularly makes the trip over here for the food and drink! I'll not add much to everyone else's opinions - quite good value for money, great food, busy and bustling atmosphere, and interesting drinks menu. Loved the Horchata and Agua Fresca, but loved even more the Cactus dishes last summer - please bring these back for your Summer menu! Chocolate con Churros was very good - as is the salsa and guacamole. Must say the service has remained the same good standard all times I've been there to eat (4 or 5 now, since it opened in 2008) however some of the portions have got smaller - and the wait at busy times has increased!

vT5awH-AH8O6DJZulItH-A.text: Five star Mexican food and five star service! There is very little that you cannot like about this brightly coloured Mexican restaurant. Whilst the skulls are not to everyone's taste (although personally I love them and the whole dia los muetos theme), there is something on the menu for everyone and the staff are friendly and approachable (They were attentive, friendly and knew their menus. They offered recommendations and we found them laid back even though it was the lunch time weekend rush). People have a very unusual view of Mexican food, they think that it's all Taco's and Burrito's, where really this is more of a Americanisation. Mexican food is much more like street food, homemade snacks that you can buy on the street, very much in the same vein as Spanish tapas. I remember a few years back going to the Covent Garden branch of this small chain for a leaving party for one of my work friends who recommended we all go here. She herself was Mexican, loved this restaurant and wanted us to share some 'real' Mexican food (or the closest thing that she could find to her home cuisine) with us. I was under the impression at the time that this was quite an expensive place. However being a work's thing and not picking up the bill, this was probably more to do about the amount that we ordered and drunk! So visiting the Shepherd's Bush branch in Westfield's I was pleasantly shocked to see how inexpensive this restaurant actually is. The food is fantastic, and whilst you can order yourself a Burrito or main, you can also order a number of smaller dishes and sides (very much like you would if you were ordering Tapas), which allows you to sample and share a number of delightful, fresh and tasty dishes rather than having to stick to one. Burritos are about the same cost as if you went to the more fast-food orientated burrito take-away restaurants you find around London. However this experience is more appealing; you don't feel rushed and can sit back and enjoy the décor (skulls and all), lovely glasses which are handmade and made from recycled glass and pleasant atmosphere. I also fell in love with their Tequila selection and cocktails. They have some fantastic choices which were extremely quaffable! I tried the passion fruit margarita and the tequila mojito and could not fault either. This place has now become a frim favourite London Mexican eatery.

aKlhlUY9XH7KFgPOrW0WSA.text: Having heard people rave about Wahaca (as the only place in London you can get authentic Mexican street food) so I thought would give it a try.Friday night dining at the Wahaca at Westfield and to begin with the queue was not so bad...we got a table in ten minute... So a good start.The service was so so...nothing to grumble about.The food was split into two categories...small plate....and large plates. You can order a couple of small plates and mix the type of food you get...or go for a large plate and just have that. All in all the favours were okay. I confess it was not really the flavours I would usually go for...I have eaten mexican before and have enjoyed it...but this didn't do it for me. Everyone else in the restaurant seemed to enjoy it so I guess i was the one out of place.It was surprising cheap around GDP28 for two people. So all said and done I would say give this place a try - though I make no promises.

lyMMJ5-vKaHiUJXuSeY4-A.text: Okay, lets be honest, Wahaca is not authentic Mexican, but guess what, it is *damn* good nuevo-Mexican.I lived near the Mexican border for 8 years and visited many times and can clearly state that if you have ever eaten Mexican "street food," you have got yourself a crap shoot at best. (You can't safely drink water in a lot of places.) Also, Mexico isn't the most vegetarian friendly country on the map.Now let's talk about what counts, the food! The street food options are delicious. The Broad Bean and Feta Taquitos and the Summer Vegetable Tacos highlight a menu with plenty of veg options. The Black Bean and Cheese Quesadillas are a great traditional option. The sides of corn and frijoles are also excellent. I would be totally remiss not to mention the Tortilla Soup which has a great warm flavor with a mild spice. Definitely a good option. If you want to try a unique drink, I recommend the Horchata (Citrus Fizz is good too) which is almond and rice milk with cinnamon. Yum! This pricing is great because you can piece your meal together at different price points depending on how hungry you are.While it is true that the service can be a bit pokey at times, I am learning that London isn't really renowned for its restaurant staff prowess. Funny how not working for a tip does that...

o7GSJcDIOo1RSkR-uYd8Qg.text: Westfield's South Terrace comprises a number of restaurants that are well-established enough to be considered a 'chain', but still small enough that the chains are mostly restricted to a handful of branches in London / the South East. For example, Balans, Fire and Stone, Del'Aziz, Kitchen Italia - and Wahaca, which has a total of three restaurants in London only. I like Westfield's policy in this respect; there is no Pizza Express, no Ask, no Zizzi - none of the ubiquitous restaurant chains that have become too big. Although Wahaca services a high number of covers, and at times can be a little pushed in that respect, the staff are highly personable and efficient, and cope very well with what is essentially the fruits of their popularity: a high turnover! Cocktails are generally good, as is the selection of good tequilas on the menu. The street food concept is something I like, and it is done very well here. It's essentially like tapas, order a handful of mini dishes and don't worry if it's not enough - you can order more later. For me this is perfect because I often don't like to commit to a main dish that may or may not be to my taste. As for puds: the chilli chocolate ice cream was a winner. I'm a fan of both chilli and chocolate, I am relatively sceptical of putting the two together, but here it works very well. The eating experience is fun: messy but delicious.

LZK2wGh1wGjXDeMSvSBdcA.text: I really liked Wahaca for a lunch in the middle of shopping at Westfield. It was busy, good atmosphere, helpful quick service and good decor. The food was good - I didn't order anything too spectacular just a steak burrito and my partner had fish tacos but they were tasty, substantial and were spiced just right for me. The food is obviously fresh, the salad type veg are crisp and the flavours are clean. I thought the pricing was good - not ultra cheap but certainly affordable. I would certainly go here again for lunch and maybe try another branch for an evening meal - maybe somewhere just a little less hectic. Really enjoyed it overall.

72kgEnvhSpT8D9EKt3541A.text: At last, I had some really good tacos today! And, I had them at the last place I would have thought to look - The bloody mall! Now when I hear mall food, I cringe and when I hear Mexican mall food in London...well I was not expecting much at all, but the food at Wahaca was delightfully better than my preconceived notions. The part of the menu I like is the 'Street Food' section, which is comprised of little plates where you can order a few to sample different things or share. The choices are typical: tacos, taquitos, quesadillas etc, albeit much fancier and more expensive than what you'd get off a taco cart - but the base flavors are un-mistakenly authentic.I tried a few things from the 'Street Food' menu, but I think the tacos are the best (I'll stick to these next time). They are very small and served on corn tortillas, which are true to the traditional tiny street versions but like I said before these are dressed variations and incredibly tasty! - Tacos with Pork pibil (slow cooked pork) - Wonderful flavor, they definitely use authentic spices in this marinade.- Tacos with Grilled British steak - Wow, these tender meat bites are amazing! - Tacos with Chicken in Mole - I skipped this one as I was frankly a little afraid to try it given it's hard to find a great mole even in California and once you've had the real deal you just can't settle for any 'ol mole and I really didn't feel like being subjected to that level of disappointment on this afternoon. When I looked at the menu online, they had Chicken tinga as a poultry option instead, which I'd happily jump on if it were available. Be sure to leave room for a little desert to round off your meal! Dove in for a double dose of caramel with the flan and dulce de leche ice-cream. The flan was incredibly creamy and smooth. Deserts might be the one area where British ingredients help boost the favor for these Mexican recipes because I think the milk, eggs and cream in the UK are much richer and it shows in the results of this flan and ice cream - Amazing!Note: They are quite heavy handed on raw red onions as a garnish. I'm not a fan of raw onions so if you share my dislike, be sure to let the waiter know when you order.

xyS-S_WqgsIU65uDbC68jg.text: Thank goodness for Wahaca!  After some miserable "mexican" at Chiquitos (seriously only tourists go there right?) we discovered this place and when we saw even just salsa and guacamole on the menu, out of sheer desperation we had to try.  Their salsas and guacamole were delicious, the guac is made fresh and is not comparable to any other i've tried in London except my own! ;)  (free refills on the crisps too)Huge bonus to Wahaca in my book goes for having MOLE sauce (dark brown sauce whose base is chocolate and chile pepper)... they should expand on their options of food you can get with Mole sauce (right now it's only a chicken dish) as mole is soooo yummy (albeit there's is a tad too spicy) and it's super good on veggies and prawns too (the chicken dish was delish though, if you've never had mole, you simply must try!).  Had a Margarita there that tasted like a margarita an American who actually like tequilla would expect (can we say patron!?!). Prawn ceviche tacos were delicious albeit messy, all together, this place is a steal for as close as what you can get to real "mexican" or american "tex-mex" that I've had over here.  Only down side I can see is lack of dishes with mole and can someone please offer a side of fried plantains, if not here than at a cuban/latino restuarant PLEASE... much better than chips, I miss them very much.

d9wwj9a1FKDLRpexLqHYlw.text: I thought this restaurant was distinctly average.  I waited 10 minutes at the front of the line before the hostess would even speak to me.  Then, she was able to seat me promptly even though no tables had cleared up in that period, so it was obviously a pointless wait.  The atmosphere is nice if you like loud restaurants (tall ceilings, cool furniture and decorations).As for the food itself, it wasn't bad value for London (I always expect larger portions than I get here), but I thought my guacamole (served with pork shavings/rinds, which I had never had) and enchilada (one of the molé ones) were distinctly bland.  The one exception was the horchata almond & rice drink, which was great.I probably will keep up my quest for a good Mexican joint, but not here.I probably won't go back

rOEqoPyWtjYLsbylAKetmg.text: This is a belated review as I was here two months ago. Honestly, apart from the guacamole and chips that were semi-authentic, there's nothing authentically Mexican about this restaurant. That's part of the reason I don't remember half of the stuff I ate here, probably some tacos and fajitas? However, I do remember that the food was DAMN GOOD! And let me warn you, their hot sauce is HOT. SO SPICY that my cheeks were all red and I needed a ton of ice and water to cool down (and I'm usually a quite extreme spicy food eater). Two things I learned from this visit: 1. Brits don't know how to pronounce Spanish words in the cutest way!! (obviously the servers have to know...I mean they better know!) haha 2. Inauthentic Mexican food is not cheap... the prices here are pretty reasonable compared to other restaurants in central London, but anyone who has ever had REAL Mexican food would know that it should be CHEAP and GOOD! Anyhow I'm just ranting because obviously this is not a authentic Mexican restaurant... well moving on...I would definitely check out the other location if I had the chance to come back to London again! xoxo!

6KBKBT-eUHPUDNYsgFFtpg.text: Wahaca is good for mexican food in London. Its over priced but all mexican food is in London. Wahaca has a few locations in London, so its a small chain. Their Tacos are very small like traditional street tacos but 10x the price £3.95-4.50 for a very small taco... thats like $6USD for one tiny tiny taco! thats a lot. I can get a taco back in California for $3 half that price, and I can get one in mexico for prob 50p or less. If you want mexican food in London your best bet is Wahaca or Lupita. I hear there are a few more hidden mexican restaurants but I don't expect to find to much more choices in London for mexican food... often English people pass of really horrible tex-mex for mexican food.blah! Example Chimichanga! never go there ever!  I mean you are in a country where 80% of the people can't pronounce Jalapeño correctly. You can't expect much... stick to Thai and Indian food when in London.

buWQUmrEIMkH3a_IikulvQ.text: The service is crap but the pork tacos are yummy.Great value for money as went with 6 girls and we only spent £12 each, including a drink! Ordered a lot of the appetiser "street food" options to share which were great. Definitely easier to get a table than in the impossibly crowded Covent Garden location but the service was pretty poor as 4 items we ordered never showed up and we didn't get our drinks until halfway through our meal.Compares pretty favourably to most Mexican options in London, but would rather have a fish taco from a Tijuana street vendor any day

5HJnDdqqHzkAymH6yRvy6w.text: This place is always lively and I love the food here. the service is getting a bit TGI fridays, which is annoying. I dont appreciate the service of 12.5% as it is often slow. Although it is a lot faster than when it first opened. For me this place is about the food and I like it. The atmosphere makes it somewhere I like to go after shopping. I get what I am expecting.

-pjYC8IlNDSDAFflby6SfQ.text: Halleluyah--there is the semblance of decent Mexican food in London!  Of course you must go to the mall to get it and it has it's UK twist--free range, organic, MSC certified.  (And of course they decided to spell Oaxaca as Wahaca so that the UK would know how to say it.  And the queso fresco is feta at least according to my taste buds.But onto all the good!  There were authentic flavors and spices, a bit of creativity, and a lesson in Oaxaca market culture.  The pork pibil tacos were very very good.  Had an interesting winter salad with roasted butternut squash (ok, not so Mexican, but I needed some vitamins).  And the chorizo and potato quesadilla was good.  Margarita was decent (again, sorry kids, I lived in Cali for the past 5 years so I have a high bar) and they have a good selection of tequilas and encourage sipping not shooting.  And you need to order chips which is a bummer.The host was excellent, the waitress a bit ditzy, but you can't have it all.  This place is a must if you need a bite after shopping.

2cTAhwGPscrBtk8K-OWx5w.text: Clearly I'm obsessed with Wahaca as this is my second visit in a week. But really, it's just because I had *planned* to come to this one anyway last night, but the Sunday night visit to the Covent Garden branch was spontaneous.Anyway, while the Westfield version lacks some of the charm and excitement of the other, I'm still very happy to see it here, amongst a bunch of crap. My friend who dined with me here last night likens Westfield to the cruise ship in Wall-E and I couldn't agree more. At least Wahaca is outside!Try the hibiscus margaritas. You won't be sorry. Your wallet might.Also, the tortilla soup is awesome -- all the bulky ingredients are sitting in the bowl, which is brought to your table with a jug of the tomatoey, spicy broth that you pour over and mix in. Fun!

5FWCnDjo21uRY69dK5xl_g.text: nice atmosphere but pricey for such small dishes.we left feeling hungry after about 1 hr.A nice touch were the little books which hubby thought were matches, i asumed toothpics but it was infact chilli seeds. Altogether the food was tasty and popular

nuKXaDy-sbqg4oDFARidgA.text: How could I have missed this place on my previous visits to Westfields? Well, from the outside it looks just as sterile and boring like all the other places, and Wahaca just doesn't mean anything to me. Boring logo, I just ignored it before. For some strange reason it really appealed today, coming from the Wood Lane end (rather than Shepherds Bush). What drew me in, though, was the sign claiming Wahaca had been voted best cheap eat by the Observer - perfect endorsement in hard times.The seats outside are either extremely low or extremely high, but once you sit down it actually has quite a nice atmosphere.I really like Mexican food, but hate tex-mex chains. This is different in just the right way. A bit like a Mexican Massala Zone with its emphasis on street/market food.We had a lovely starter, sharing a tapas portion of cactus plant on taco chips and then went for the chicken burritos. They come with tacos and a lovely home-made salsa on the side.Also, I have a thing for restaurants that offer interesting soft drinks. We had a lovely lime/mint and hibiscus/cranberry drink - a lovely alternative to diet coke or overpriced mineral water!Would have like to order a dessert, but the portions are very filling.Went for coffee instead (espresso is great for caffeine addicts like me, but the Americano almost knocked my less addicted boyfriend off his seat - luckily we were on the low recliners rather than bar stools!). The chilli chocolate on the side was a very nice touch.And what we first thought were matches, turned out to be little seed sticks to grow your own chillis at home.A new favourite!

E04mp0JyIf1qA__be7ZJSA.text: Great concept with brilliant execution. Superb food - ingredients sourced as locally as possible, inspiration from the Mexican markets - it's consistently good and fun. I've been taken through the menu here by a few people in the know - it fully knocked my socks off. I'm normally an adventurous type and will go for the things I haven't heard of before - if you're not, do make an effort to do so here. It's the stuff you wouldn't normally order that shines out. The chocolatey mole, the fish tacos, the black bean soup... well, you can see plenty of others waxing lyrical on the topic down below my writings. But, you know, even if you're not feeling adventurous, something like the sharing selection for two is comprehensive and equally tasty and good quality. I was there when the top deck was closed off for the night - I went up to take in the view and couldn't help but enjoy watching everyone downstairs clattering and chattering, and mostly getting overexcited about their plastic spoons.

t26sH9PRqTe2uLk6Jy6dxw.text: Wahaca at Westfield has been reviewed extensively so I'll spare you exhaustive details on the food. Suffice it so say, the food is excellent - with freshness, flavour and interest the driving motivation. Service was friendly and fun. Food arrives suprisingly quickly. There are excellent (top-flight) tequilas as well as delicious non-alcoholic cocktails. We had a lovely time and I recommend it for a fun time with friends.

z5bXzPml0kikQVnSUuvYPA.text: Before going on an extended vacation to England with my sis, I researched Mexican food joints for us to check out. This place seemed to have promise. I came here under the illusion that I'd be eating Mexican style "street food" and I was gravely mistaken. Being from LA, I've had my fair share of Mexican cuisine but not even the worst places I've visited can compare to my experience at Wahaca. The name itself should have clued me in (being an anglicized version of Oaxaca).  I recall having a quesadilla while my sister had a burrito of some sort. They were both horrible. Just overall atrocious. Both meals lacked in the flavor department and contained some very unorthodox ingredients (which did not help their cause in the least). I believe the salsa wasn't any good either. How difficult can it be to make a descent taco? Even Santa Barbara has some pretty great food which is saying a lot considering the demographic.I suppose if you haven't eaten authentic Mexican food, you can't compare the two and therefore know just how bad the imitation is. If you haven't tried genuine Mexican food than this may be your cup of tea but, you're missing out.Needless to say, on my last venture to Mexico, a "street" taco cost me $5 (in Mexican pesos which is equivalent to less than 50 American cents) and it was actually good. The Pros: The ambiance had some character and our waiter was very friendly and not at all bad to look at.

bcsTajBGfFnAc8fepgrE6A.text: I usually judge Mexican food by the salsa, the guacamole, the street tacos, the quesadillas and the margaritas. My night of tasting the delights here met my approval for having the best Mex this side of the Atlantic. My cravings finally have a place to go to be filled (cuz God help me I'm American and need my south of the border fix on a regular basis). The guacamole had great flavor and had nice chunks of avocado. This is a huge plus for me since I could eat this stuff with a spoon and forget the crisps. I went through two bowls of salsa verde. Some people use sauces to cover up foods. There was nothing wrong with the food... I has a second helping just so I could dunk soft tortillas in it to lap up its goodness. The quesadillas...oh good golly... the crazy mushroom quesadilla that was creamy and gooey and unpronounceable. It's a fungus that grows on corn. Seriously. Can I just say it's the best damn fungus I've ever tried because I will be back for more. Then, the pork tacos. Three small soft corn tortillas, fresh and dripping with oil, filled with a saucy pulled pork and covered in pickled veg were spot on. They were a bit fancier than the normal street taco that I'm used to, but they were great little starter bites -- again, dunked into that super salsa verde. While I didnt test a margarita there, I did try the blanco, reposado and anejo Corralejo tequilas in the Wahaca designed tumblers. Nice touch. I sampled so many delicious dinner items, and finished off with some heavenly decadent churros, that I would like to go back for a repeat of a few things and then continue sampling the other items on the menu. I dont think that anything would disappoint me since my basic needs have been met. Besides, I totally bought into the locally sourced, Mexican inspired menu. I love a restaurant with a conscience and passion for great tasting, sustainable food. ...This location would also be great for sunny days. Lots of outdoor seating and the front of the restaurant opens up completely. Cant wait to head there in the summer for quacamole and a cold cerveza!

4obNrPoU0yomH4JGiVVMyQ.text: Awesome ambience ,gr8 staff being my first time Wanted to explore n just enjoyed the food n placeThe manager n staff -giamono was superb , we are vegetarians n he really served us with care He get 5 starsThank u

r6W243mgVPCjkQUeqv74JQ.text: Man, I haven't even finished yet and I have to write a review. Some friends and I tried to get into the one at South Bank the other night but there was a 90-minute wait for a table, so I knew I had to pop in another time. When I found it at Westfield in Shepherds Bush, I had to jump in. I've ordered a sweet potato side, slow-cooked pork burrito and the Tequila Experience. Sweet potato - I don't know what they've done to it but I've never had anything like it. Crispy on the outside and so smooth and sweet in the middle. Perfection. I've made the mistake in the past of eating traditional Mexican before and adding cheese to the burrito. I learnt my lesson that time. The pork is so tender. It falls apart in your mouth. Jesus would say "Fuck you, Judas, I'm hanging around," if this were served at the Last Supper. And the tequila! I've only had two of the three but they are so smooth, babies' arses everywhere are jealous. Looking forward to the last. This is a must-do if you like food and you're in London. I will be returning again before I leave.

StBEK3GqGRDZ8-bS7FJPwA.text: For the last week I've been in two different Wahaca restaurants and the service was terrible in both. Food is tasty! The environment is really interesting and nice but the service is just really bad. Waiting for ages for everything - order, drinks, bill. Bad. Bad. Bad. Its putting me off every time I want to enjoy their food.

McekQi85aLupP6OQKWcy2w.text: Okay, so, this is really not 'authentic' Mexican food. More like Mexican-inspired.On the other hand, if we disregard that, it's pretty decent. I really like their taquitos and the drinks, and it has a pretty nice atmosphere. I wouldn't come here alone, it's definitely a place for friends to share. That said, their tapas are small. Good, but quite small for the price. I did like the chicken dish I ordered just for myself this one time though, it was spiced quite well and the cilantro rice was yummy. Staff was friendly but kind of scattered especially during busy hours - not really their fault, though.

AZRtoe2B1omPs2M1XdQ5kw.text: I usually try to stay away from eating at Malls, but apparently like in the developing world, London has legitimate restaurants attached to fancy malls. I met with a friend for lunch and settled on some Mexican, and I can say that I was very satisfied with that decision. Service was excellent. They took great care of us making sure our drinks were always full and that the food was to our satisfaction. They left nothing to be desired on this one. Drinks, we had different Margaritas and shared. I loved mine, she loved hers, we didn't like each others'....inconclusive! lol.The food was good. The British Steak taco was flavorful, the pork pibil taco (like BBQ pulled pork), was so-so. I then ordered the jazzed up Green rice and the Frijoles (refried beans and chorizo sausage) which are two different side dishes but were made for each other. Rice and beans are a quintessential dish and I wasn't about to miss out! I don't know why they don't sell those two together, because they are awesome combined! A couple of margaritas and there must have been some other food ordered but I'm ashamed to say that I they weren't memorable enough apparently. If you need a Mexican fix in London, the mall is legit. TIP: The only thing that I would have done differently is that they have on the menu a 2 person platter for £20 with a lot of food. Next time I'll get that instead of buying everything piecemeal, my wallet would have preferred that.

ViuHooYTpH9EtbJz4pDw6g.text: nice atmosphere but pricey for such small dishes.we left feeling hungry after about 1 hr.A nice touch were the little books which hubby thought were matches, i asumed toothpics but it was infact chilli seeds.Altogether the food was tasty and popular

jKKWSya4MhKIfeVriSwN1g.text: If I could give less I would.. The food was bland the black beans were an over kill and tasteless the staff was so inattentive they served me tap water in a dirty glass with a bean stuck to it.. Idk if I'm so disappointed because I'm Mexican but I guess you get what you can here

LzrcemJup3DV3UTDO3DpOQ.text: When i was in London, i was in a bit of a Latin withdrawal crisis.  I'll admit maybe i was a bit homesick... so Wahaca was amazing.  My buddy and i created a Wahaca Wednesday tradition.  They have great drinks, great soft tacos and omg the guacamole.  The location at Shepherds Bush is ideal, not too crowded.

nkbSpxgmB4zrHYP4CD3Hgw.text: I feel sorry for you Brits when this is considered the best Mexican restaurant in London.My complaints...1. Guacamole should be made to order not "made every day". When our order came, it was slightly brown. Fresh guacamole should be bright green.2. The MSC fish tacos - my goujons were burnt to a dark brown. It looked like pieces of turd. Fried fish in tacos should be fried to a light golden color. Also, the fish just seemed like it's processed & not fresh by the shape & the batter. It shouldn't be the shape of a fish stick (or as you Brits call it...a fish finger).  I did enjoy my tamarind magarita & the tortillas from my fish tacos with the smoky chipotle salsa.Maybe the meat items are better and more authentic.

VWwRz7qmXj0N5ofEaDiXbw.text: So what would you expect for £10  per person? (shared set plates) To be honest after a hard days graft following Mrs F around Westfields then I would pay that just to be greeted by friendly staff.The food was tasty samples of Mexican street food... ??? More Mexican meets noveau cuisine, still good and enough to fill my tummy.Will return on my next shopping expedition

qroM001Ge9zQKE_wZsdjRA.text: This is some decently respectable Mexican food, amazingly enough in a Westfield mall on the west side of London.We started with guacamole and chips. The chips were excellent. The guac seemed pretty fresh though the too-much lime made me wonder if they were trying to hold onto the freshness too much.The tacos were very good -- you could tell the tortillas were fresh and the meat was very tender. The ceviche was pretty good but not out of this world.For a very affordable and convenient meal with friendly service, I recommend this place. The portions were actually quite filling and it makes for a fun experience to share a bunch of tiny dishes.Gluten-free notes: They're able to tell you what is and isn't gluten-free on the menu. You'll have a good selection. Three cheers for corn tortillas.

5HWles86ImQ1iRTKRgm9Vg.text: Being from Los Angeles, I was really REALLY craving some decent Mexican food. I wasn't expecting too much since the other "Mexican" food I've had in London has been some awful, flavourless rendition of the stuff you can find in any tiny taqueria in LA. Well, damn, I got my fix. I went for it, and basically ordered everything I could off the "tapas" part of the menu. I really wanted taquitos. So I ordered those, tostadas, tacos and a burrito. I ordered everything vegan, and I was really surprised at all the flavours!Tacos: really tasty, didn't need extras.Taquitos: shell kind of too thick, but the flavours were great.Tostada: very fresh, in-season vegetablesBurrito: Only had a tiny taste, as it was for my boyfriend. Really tasty, and the best one I've had in London, so far. (It's really hard to get a decent burrito here!)I can't really give a review for the meat products... before I went veg, I'd had my fair share of meaty Mexican food, so I do wonder how flavourful and authentic it is in that respect.Overall, as a veg, I give it a thumbs up. I won't say it's authentic (authentic usually means it has lard), but it's really satisfying and tasty. The only thing I didn't like was that the guacamole seemed kinda watery and weird. I love a good, chunky, creamy guac, but it didn't taste horrible.I came to this location in the day time during lunch, and there was hardly anyone in there... but it quickly filled up in the time I consumed my meal. They don't allow you to book a table, but I think it's worth it, if you want a great burrito/taco in London.

UAmWjsFnArvOQvk6qiLwLA.text: I'm really, really REALLY impressed with Wahaca's new 09/10 "cold months" menu. In particular, I love the smoked herring tostadas and the Baja California fish tacos. I also love the fact that they serve (and as far as I know are the only restaurant that serves) horchata. YUMMY! It's an attractive space too (much like their Covent Garden restaurant) and appears to be the most popular eatery at Westfield ... but don't let the long queues put you off. They tend to move along at a steady pace and even if you have to wait a little while, it's well worth it. Good, hearty, feel good Mexican food. Awesome.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

G1ODr2jPqAtsqwCDUUe5Rw.text: Ok, the food is good run-of-the-mill Mexican. It really reminded me of the stuff I've had in the US, circa my frequent stays there in the early 2000's. Now we Brits haven't been exposed to half decent Mexican food on this kind of scale before, so I can see how it seems easy for the Brits to get a bit carried away with Wahaca sometimes.Tasty food, burrito was good but why do I have to pay extra for cheese? Seems to me this is a staple thing, but hey ho. I'm a sucker for melted cheese and so I was probably going to be happy with anything that came in a folded flour tortilla and I wasn't disappointed.The prices are low, which I guess is probably the best thing about the place. The hibiscus drink was pretty nice too.Our server was a little surly. And did the old trick of forcing tap water on a colleague of mine. Naughty waiter. He wasn't the best server and I felt pretty disgruntled about the added service charge when there was only 5 of us. Dude - you're getting your tip, so, at least try and be nice to us! Overall this is canteen food and everything about the place from the seating to the Wagamama-style paper menus was designed to get us in and out of the place quickly. If the prices had been higher this place would've got a lot less stars. As it is, you get what you pay for. Done.

8RakksQJiZb8PYSPiN7Rig.text: Full disclosure: if the prices were a little lower, this would be four stars. To begin, is anyone actually expecting authentic mexican street food here? Really? Go here expecting some mexican-inspired food and I think you'll be pleased. We had some delicious and very crunchy tortilla chips with so-so guacamole, my fiancée had an absolutely first-rate cheese-and-mushroom melt thing (queso fundido) and pork tacos, and I had a vegetable burrito. She said her tacos were delicious. As for the burrito, it was great - and again, nothing like what you'd find on a mexican street corner. There was squash and feta cheese in it, for heaven's sake. It was absolutely tasty and I could eat another one right now, but authentic? Psssssh.We didn't go in expecting authentic food and were pleased with what we got. I absolutely recommend that you do the same, should you find yourself in the area of the Westfield mall and craving something... mexican-esque. Oh, and props to our waiter - he was quick and attentive, and brought us a refill on our chips right on time. Nice!

lCy2ChWN7sHfWf-BaLPeyg.text: I've been to Wahaca a few times (well, this was the third...) and always this branch. Whilst meaning to try one of the other ones I always seem to just end up at the Westfield branch, and so far I haven't been too disappointed. A massive fan of sharing plates and the tapas style approach (probably stemming from the fact I can never make up my mind what to have, so having some of everything works in my favour) we had dishes of the street food - some tacos - pork pibil and chicken tinga, MSC ceviche tostada, chorizo and potato quesadilla and one of their new specials - the Huarache (or slipper!). We also had some spicy slaw on the side. I love their pork pibil, I've had that as one of the bigger mains (they do those as well as the street food dishes and it was good), so I enjoyed that. The chicken was alright but nothing special. I'm not a fan of seafood so didn't really enjoy the ceviche tostada (scallops and prawns) but that's not their fault! The quesadilla was fantastic, as was the Huarache and slaw. However overall the bread/wraps they used just didn't taste right, but I'm not exactly sure why, just a bit tasteless. Drinks were good and my tequila chocolate toddy shot to conclude the meal was heart warming and had a great alcohol hit to it. Incredible. However service was a bit worse than usual, taking ages for the dishes to arrive, even though they were all piling up on the pass. And to get the bill took a while - noone seemed to be looking at us even though we were trying to get their attention! Ah well. I've liked it before but this visit was under par, but I'll go again, and rather tempted to try one of the other locations out as well to see if there's a difference.

uAsAMoyT6MNpO_6x2gbqGw.text: I've wandered past Wahaca often, and always be vaguely intrigued...plus the boy has always assured me that the food is delicious. We finally got around to making a trip on Saturday, and it left me with slightly mixed sentiments. Some of the food is, indeed, delicious. The chorizo and potato quesadillos, the pork pibil and the MSC ceviche were gorgeous - beautifully spiced, lovely flavours and all very more-ish. We also tried the Huarache (black beans, salsa, feta...), which was very pleasant, and the chicken tinga tacos (lovely chicken, not keen on the sauce). To be honest, the main disapointment of the food was the tortillas themselves, which didn't quite manage either a taste or a texture that enthralled me. But that can be over-looked, given the tasty fillings. For once, I decided to have a dessert too. Now that was a disappointment. I like churros - I've had them in Spain a few times - and they've always been tasty and surprisingly un-greasy...well, not here. The oiliness and lack of flavour of the churros made me regret ordering a dessert at all, even though the chocolate sauce was lovely and the boy's chill choclate tequilla toddy was quite surprisingly yummy. So the dessert disappointed. But there was another reason why I couldn't push my score up; the service. Now, I have to say that the staff were all delightfully friendly, polite and willing to help and make suggestions. It's just getting them to pay attention that's a little hard. In fairness to them, they have a lot of tables to look after and it was busy, but when you have to sit holding your empty glass desperatley trying to catch someone's eye as they walk past you not once, not twice, not even just three times...well, it's not the best of situations. Still, whilst I may not decide to go back there myself, I would certainley not turn it down as a suggestion. And there are a few things I wouldn't mind trying next time I visit...

Z44Jnc6twEB5wXO6x-7vGg.text: Things I like:Fish tacosHorchataThings I dislike:FISHY tacosThe extreme overuse of raw red onionSpicy guacamole (also with lots of raw red onion; see above)Cold, rubbery corn tortillasShitty serviceNot receiving an apology for, nay even an acknowledgement of, said shitty serviceI was going to give Wahaca 4 stars at the start of the meal, but as more food arrived and more raw red onion was consumed, I knocked the rating down to three.  And then when two of the street food items I ordered never arrived at the table and I had to flag down our server to ask about them, and that server never even acknowledged that something was awry despite his having to reorder the items, I was miffed.  And then when I had to flag down the server AGAIN just to ask for the bill, and he responded monosyllabically and then got another server to give it to us, that was it for me.Two stars.Did I mention how much raw red onion there was?  No one needs that much raw red onion.

dqq0p3p2nmsmJ-f98hGtEA.text: Perfect for a break from trawling through the best mall in London, Wahaca is a buzzing haven. I recently tried the Soho branch and enjoyed the experience so much that when my friend suggested the Westfield branch the other day, I readily agreed. This time we went for the sharing platter of 5 dishes - the pok pilbil tacos, seasonal vegetarian tacos, corn quitlacoche quesadillas and chicken taqitos and black bean tostadas - all for £19.95.This was a pretty decent spread for the price - truth be told we probably didn't even need that much food. Their own made soft drinks are lovely; my friend waxed lyrical over the almond and rice milk iced drink with cinnamon, while I liked the sweet and fresh hibiscus water made with cranberry both for £1.40.Lovely food, messy, authentic, friendly and colourful.

kMnoFxuvlipQUnh90X0rfQ.text: I'm a lover of Mexican food (and all Latin American food, for that matter), so I was really excited to visit Wahaca, seeing quite good reviews. I went with a friend, and my opinion is a bit mixed. The service was quite nice and our food came out immediately, but to me honest food coming out in about 5 minutes makes me a bit concerned about the quality of the food, how long it's been sitting there, etc. I liked what I had ordered, I believe it was a Potato Taquito and a shrimp ceviche, in fact I really loved the ceviche, which had a nice fresh flavor. However, my friend couldn't finish his food because he disliked it so much. I had a bite of his chicken taco, and he was right, it was quite bland. I didn't dare try his British steak taco (of course, why buy English food where the specialty is Mexican, but I digress...), but I trusted his judgment. I can't give Wahaca more than a 3, considering my friend (a real meat lover) hated his meal, yet I quite liked mine. I'd like to go one more time though to sample a few more and really get a feel of it :]

L0l9iwtaa9GCubfCkSz-7w.text: If in need of Mexican food while in London this is a good place.  Service is pretty close to 5 stars.  Good staff, the plates come out fast, and they do a good job of clearing the table in a timely mannerThe food itself is 4+ stars.The only thing that really keeps me from giving a 5 start rating is the ambiance.  It's just real noisy. It's real easy to get here via tube.  If you drive, parking at Westfield can be challenging, but be patient and you'll find a spot.

Kemy1g0XW2pD5zo1XPZZAg.text: Came here upon a recommendation from a local friend as it was good Mexican food. I do have to say the location is pretty great, being right at westfield mall but the noise level inside the restaurant was way too much for me, I could barely hear my dad across the table from me.I did not find the food to be authentic or spicey in the slightest. There was some flavor but nothing like what I am used to. One thing that really threw me was that the nachos have melted liquid cheese on them? Nachos are supposed to have melted shredded cheese on them, ours were soggy and pretty bland. Upon paying we waited for nearly 10 minutes for some change which we thought rather odd, no one in the restaurant had a 5? Overall it was okay food at a good location.

wbKXjQ0u57PLfFcvSEyqfg.text: I went on Taco Tuesday and was disappointed to learn that certain tacos are excluded (including the fish tacos, etc). However, I really enjoyed the plantain taco. The guacamole and chips were decent. The customer service was great.

-C3exYlzzCevG06Z7qNuIQ.text: Very nice staffJust the food is not my typeI tried the Mexican Feast, £42 for two...Nice restaurant Good feeling, soft light I feel like I am in a forest Because the outside are so green!!

9x_xV7AXx29D_7-vSVl1_g.text: Really pretty bad... but then, who goes for Mexican in a London shopping mall?  I knew it was a bad idea, but I was with a group, and they were unwilling to change plans.  Menu didn't make a lot of sense (hummus and feta in a Mexican restaurant?)  Chips were stale, and guac was flavourless. Do yourself a favour and go somewhere else. Anywhere else. Anywhere. Really.

JG5uEVjd3TMG_iZQXAO2GA.text: As the three stars suggests, this is a mixed review.Drinks were excellent (i had a pear/vodka cocktail) although we had to ask twice for tap water.The guacamole was really tasty with such good corn chips - wonder if they buy them or make them on site.The crispy prawns taco starter was really good - tasted very fresh with the right balance of flavours.However, I found my main very disappointing. I had the Poblano & tomatillo enchilada and just found it crazy rich. It was swimming in a creamy sauce without any tomato or anything to cut through. So much cheese too (and I love cheese). I had to use a lot of hot sauce just to cut through all the richness.I probably would return if I were at westfield but I'd pick a 'fresher' dish.

6DX0SJyv6GSC5EnovCgUBw.text: I tried the fish tacos and chicken tostados. The fish tacos were alright, but don't come close to the ones in California. The cold chicken tostados were very bland...tasted like canned chicken with some guacamole mixed in. It's not real Mexican food and not as good as the Mexican food in California. But it's also not horrible. It's good service, a clean restaurant, lively atmosphere, great location, etc.

i0WXfH44F7S9ITMrXi3eBg.text: Stopped by for an afternoon snack, friendly staff, quick service, tasty food and fun/relaxed environment. Couldn't wish for more.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Inside the restaurant
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Guacamole with tortilla chips and a Citrus Fizz

UYkgdpeENQvsAcoSVO_8yg.text: If you ask me, I am not a massive mMexican fan and I would never have walked into this restaurant. Luckily I was invited and I ate here.To my surprise this place is actually really tasty and priced very reasonably.there is a huge selection of street food as well as the normal main courses including tacos burritos fish chicken beef...you name it. They also do special drinks and virgin cocktails which were all very tasty. We ordered so much (almost one of each)I cannot possibly remember which dish is which.This place is very good for groups if you like sharing or if you want to try lots of dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom

9z4WNP5bKII7MIZpLRjvQA.text: No, it isn't perfect. No, it isn't a family run, hole in the wall. As a Californian I should stay away out of respect. However, they have a decent tequila menu and make a nice passion fruit margarita. I usually order the sweet potato taquitos, and something from the evening specials or the sonora steak salad. The side of sweet potatoes are sweet and spicy and my husband really likes their burritos. The staff tends to be a bit dazed and confused, but there are a couple good servers at this location.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Post yoga passion fruit margarita.

UfoQdurWL2IA3TN2nvbndw.text: Excellent waitress. Food was on point and even got service Empanadas at the end of the night. So glad I can grab a bite after work at 10pm.

AQDvg0eyvDVUA8CaRvT8Jg.text: I like Wahaca, I like the way the menu is structured, the little plates for sharing, there is choice without it being overwhelming; the food is tasty and arrives quite quickly. The kitchen staff is impeccable. However the waiting staff is slow, some of them a plain rude. We ordered our drinks, nothing too complicated, mine came wrong and the waitress just dumped it on the table and left before I got the chance to say it's wrong. An other waitress apologies and took it away and it took 20min to get the right one. After my friend asked 3 times if we can order we finally did. I do like this place, but the staff gets worse and worse

5OQeg3mDPhdQDNOwq8nUaw.text: Super cheap and yummy Mexican, sadly, only average service.  The hubby and I shared chips & salsa, chicken tinga and pork pibil.  We both loved the kick in the chicken tinga...as well as the extra kick provided from the fiery sauces on the table.  My pure classic margarita was delicious but a bit on the small size.  If you're gonna put a ton of ice cubes in my alcoholic bevvy, at least fill it completely to the top of the tiny glass!   We visited Wahaca on an early Sunday afternoon...a time in which it seemed that 50% of the tables had young children eating.  Not sure what this place is like in the evenings, but steer clear on Saturday/Sundays lunches if you can't handle a "yelping" child or two.  :)

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Wahaca Seating

W76j68wmTS5QG22gvIDBkA.text: Wahaca is a great place for a casual dinner which is fun, interesting and tasty. 3 of us enjoyed some small plates, the Wahaca selection plate is a good choice as it showcases a good variety of items from the small plates section and saves you alittle money too. Favourites include quesadilla (both mushroom and the famous chorizo and potato are great) the taquitos, crispy tortilla rolls filled with lovely fillings, topped with salad, sour cream, cheese and tomato. Infact, many things here are served with a little pile of salad, which makes me very happy! We also tried the fish tacos between us, lovely, fresh salad and crispy fish, served with a surprisingly flavourful rice and beans. I would say that the small plates, tapas style, are better than the large plates, they are better value for money, tastier and showcase a wider range of flavours. Dessert was a shot of chocolate, which is different to the usual hot chocolate, closer to proper drinking chocolate, chocolate cake, which was abit boring and........churros! Now shoot me down for saying this but I've never had churros before and I have to say, this place has ruined me for churros for the rest of my life because they were awesome; crispy, crunchy, soft in the middle, slightly fatty tasting, in the best possible way and served with caramel dipping sauce......totally yummy!We also enjoyed some nice cocktails; Hibiscus margarita and Hibiscus Mojito but the menu showcases quite afew interesting options, soft drinks sounded nice too. All in all, an enjoyable meal, food is served very quickly, is fresh and moreish and good value, this places gets busy though so go super early!

T76P25cMgqAdOZrtoA_4dA.text: Met my sister-from-another-mister here a month ago. Hayfever was KILLING me, omg it was so bad and I needed a) to hide inside b) some alcohol to numb the histamines a little. I also needed about a thousand tissues for the almost constant sneezing I and the other diners were subjected to.The service was a little slow unfortunately but the food was good: I had a burrito, my SfaM had something veggie which she liked and we shared some.....broccoli?? That doesnt sound right, but Im sure it was broccoli!Anyway, handy location, wasnt really busy so we got a table immediately and food OK. I'd probably come back if I was at Westfield and wanted 'Mexican', though there is another one inside right!?

SAUkj2_3uKnZxGEY1W-Htg.text: First off, this is not Mexican food. There is feta. There is a distinct lack of authenticity throughout. It claims to be authentic and Mexican. As someone who has eaten a lot of Mexican food in both the US and in Mexico, this is neither authentic Mexican, Tex-Mex nor anything in between. Also: Oaxaca. Don't treat your audience as idiots.Now that that's out of the way, I can review this place for the general tastiness of food and such. Decent enough dinner, if a bit tiny. They say that the "street food" dishes are designed to be shared tapas style. This would work if they weren't so measly. For the most part, however, they tasted alright. Our server was a touch slow, but very responsive and friendly. The best part of the meal was the churros. Fresh, cinnamony, and with a nice chocolate sauce Still. Not Mexican. But a decent meal out if you want something Mexican-ish.

-XhcZc3R4tz7nNQOxTuqzA.text: I ordered the Beef Burrito and was disappointed with the actual amount of beef in it. Just a few strips and the rest was filling (rice, beans, cabbage, green rice, etc.).The ambiance was nice, but not Mexican at all. The music selection was mostly Salsa and Cumbia. Not very Mexican.To me, this was more of a Tex-Mex restaurant, but the flavor was not what you'd find in Texas or Mexico. There are other dishes on the menu that sound appetizing but I'm not sure I'd return to try them.Then again, the restaurant was pretty packed so they must be doing something right.

photos.caption: Photo of Wahaca - London, United Kingdom. Wahaca sauces

TCMpA5gcOmTJcM-cG1JRhw.text: Wah-can-i-say?! Its super good! I know my tacos being from Southern California, The pork pibil tacos have great flavour and though they are a bit on the small side theres a small price attached to them. £4 for 3 mini tacos. This may not be proper street style, but i think the flavours are there and they are delicious. I love the tequila options and the fact that they have jamaica and horchata. SO good! I eat here when I start to miss mexican food.

rUvtT5hNGooRcylswHAy1g.text: If you have ever had Mexican food prepared by Mexicans in a restaurant owned by Mexicans, or anything even close, you will be disappointed by Wahaca. As the spelling of Oaxaca suggests, this is "Mexican" food for people who have no idea what Mexican food actually is. It is very creamy and tastes almost Italian influenced. The chips were cardboard covered in sour cream. The "avocado salsa" in my burrito contained zero avocado. Do the chefs ever see fresh tomatillo? Probably not. To be fair, I shouldn't have expected so much coming from Los Angeles to a place that has very very few Latinos. Stars for a clean, friendly and well-managed chain. The quality of the ingredients were fine, just definitely NOT authentic Mexican. I would honestly rather go to Chipotle.

8c_gtLf1SdkqCNiJxARvXw.text: Decent enough Mexican-inspired food without blowing my socks off - a nice enough location with friendly staff. I enjoyed some things more than others; highs and lows really emphasising the average star rating I have given with this review.I want to emphasise the Mexican street food INSPIRED nature of the food on offer; I don't think anything there would be welcomed as authentic by Mexicans or true fans of their food, but that doesn't mean parts weren't tasty. I just think describing dishes as "truly authentic" Mexican then throwing in feta, or Lancashire cheddar, is a bit of a mixed message.My favourite dishes were the spicy pork tacos, the queso fundido (which wasn't so much cheese fondue as a cheese-sauce-topping for some cactus leaves, but was delicious anyway) and their "citrus fizz" drink (basically a non-alcoholic mojito). I was extremely disappointed however with their chicken taquitos. Described as "tender, marinated chicken" it was actually rock hard, burnt and tasteless chicken owing in part to the deep frying. It may well have been tender and marinated before it went in the fryer, but it was completely ruined. My wife and I went tapas style, grabbing a load of smaller plates to share - however we couldn't share the pork tacos as they came with beans (not advertised) and my wife hates them. So that too was disappointing.All in all, if someone wanted to come here again with me, I wouldn't be against the idea - however there are many, many better options so I doubt I will be returning to Wahaca (the spelling of this name really bothers me) on my own accord.
